channel.title: Question about grub-live and writable file system
channel.description:
When I mount a Veracrypt container inside a grub-live session. The I get the red warning that there is a writable file system mounted.
Is there a chance that traces are left on my disk now? How does this work? The whole veracrypt container is written to disk? The files are? Are there no traces. Please clarify

item.title: Question about grub-live and writable file system
item.dc:creator: arraybolt3
item.description:
Reproduced issue on Kicksecure 17.4.4.6 using VirtualBox with EFI enabled.

Looks like the issue is that live-hardener tries to remount /boot/efi read-only after it mounts a read-write overlay on /boot. Mounts don’t “show through” an overlayfs, so /boot/efi isn’t even accessible in live mode, and remounting /boot/efi doesn’t do anything in this situation.

Created a fix at GitHub - ArrayBolt3/grub-live at arraybolt3/live-hardener-fix which is pending review. I’m unsure if this will end up in Kicksecure 17 or if it will have to wait until Kicksecure 18, but there’s a known fix now.

Read full topic
item.source: Question about grub-live and writable file system

item.title: Question about grub-live and writable file system
item.dc:creator: arraybolt3
item.description:
You should be able to keep using live mode without issues. The warning you see isn’t because something broke that wasn’t broken before, but because hardening features we added to make live mode more effective aren’t fully working. At worst, live mode should be at least as effective as how it used to work (assuming the only directory livecheck warns about is /boot/efi).

I’ll continue looking into this to see if I can find the bug.

Read full topic
item.source: Question about grub-live and writable file system

item.title: Question about grub-live and writable file system
item.dc:creator: Jac
item.description:
arraybolt3:

live-hardener

Thanks for your reply. Rebooting does not solve the problem. I don’t know what to do. Real-time mode is very important for me. Version 17.3.9.9. worked without problems on my computer.

Read full topic
item.source: Question about grub-live and writable file system

item.title: Question about grub-live and writable file system
item.dc:creator: arraybolt3
item.description:
That’s weird then… if live-hardener ran, /boot/efi should not be writable when booted in live mode. I’d see if the problem automatically goes away after a reboot (if you haven’t already). If it doesn’t, there’s probably a bug in live-hardener.

Read full topic
item.source: Question about grub-live and writable file system

item.dc:creator: arraybolt3
item.description:
Can you share the output of systemctl status live-hardener.service?

item.source: Question about grub-live and writable file system

item.title: Question about grub-live and writable file system
item.dc:creator: Jac
item.description:
Hello, I have a similar problem, after installing the new version of KickSecure, in live mode, I get a red icon in the upper right part of the screen. How to solve this problem? (The system is installed on the main hard drive). I am a newbie and I do not understand how to fix this

Live Mode Active: Yes (grub-live semi-persistent)
Persistent Mode Active: Yes (writable filesystems are mounted)

Changes to the system should be lost after a reboot, but this is not guaranteed.

  • The following removable media directories have a writable filesystem mounted to them:
    *none
  • The following directories have an unexpected writable filesystem mounted to them:
  • /boot/efi
    You should unmount all of the above listed directories to ensure changes made will not persist through a reboot.

Read full topic
item.source: Question about grub-live and writable file system

item.title: Question about grub-live and writable file system
item.dc:creator: arraybolt3
item.description:
The current live mode detection code isn’t Veracrypt-volume aware, so it can’t tell the difference between a container located on an ephemeral live filesystem, and a container located on a writable disk device. It just sees that you have a writable mounted device and warns you about it.

It might be possible to add code that is aware of Veracrypt volumes, but that would only make it work with Veracrypt specifically. There are a lot of applications that may mount a writable container that our code would have to be aware of, so in general this isn’t an easy problem to solve.

If the container itself is located on an ephemeral filesystem, then your writes to it should disappear on reboot, just like with any file on the ephemeral filesystem.

Read full topic
item.source: Question about grub-live and writable file system

item.title: Question about grub-live and writable file system
item.dc:creator: whkicks
item.description:
When I mount a Veracrypt container inside a grub-live session. The I get the red warning that there is a writable file system mounted.

Is there a chance that traces are left on my disk now? How does this work? The whole veracrypt container is written to disk? The files are? Are there no traces. Please clarify

Read full topic
item.source: Question about grub-live and writable file system
